content.body: foolip: I think that makes sense
I'll run a new query for all of httparchive, with pi targets [a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9-]* , excluding "xml"
zcorpan: if we define pseudo-attribute conformance properly (and it's implemented by validator.nu) do you think that changes the calculus for > vs ?> in serialization and conformance requirements?
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: if we define pseudo-attribute conformance properly (and it's implemented by validator.nu) do you think that changes the calculus for > vs ?> in serialization and conformance requirements?

content.body: foolip: I'm ok with > if the serializer omits ?. I suppose the lack of HTML parser-level parse error means some people will miss errors, but it's probably a small set of people anyway (who use an HTML parser in their pipeline but not validator.nu)
content.formatted_body: foolip: I'm ok with > if the serializer omits ?. I suppose the lack of HTML parser-level parse error means some people will miss errors, but it's probably a small set of people anyway (who use an HTML parser in their pipeline but not validator.nu)

content.body: I've been looking at how to define conformance. I think it would be something analagous to "The value attribute, if specified and not empty, must have a value that is a valid time string."
zcorpan: could we report parse errors without actually parsing?
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: could we report parse errors without actually parsing?

content.body: foolip: would need to step through new pseudo-attribute states in the tokenizer to get it right. It's overkill for just reporting errors from the parser
content.formatted_body: foolip: would need to step through new pseudo-attribute states in the tokenizer to get it right. It's overkill for just reporting errors from the parser

content.body: I proposed a change to the CSS of generated spec diffs. Which approach is more usable for screen reader users? See https://github.com/w3c/htmldiff-ui/issues/23
